questions.question: What are the standard dimensions of a full-size croquet court?

correctTheory.title: Standard Court Dimensions
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Court dimensions, standardization, playing surface
correctTheory.summary: The standard court size is exactly 35 yards by 28 yards, with the longer sides running north-south. This precise measurement is fundamental to proper hoop placement and gameplay.

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Law 2: The Court

questions.question: What is a 'triple peel' in Association Croquet?

answers.answer: Running three consecutive hoops with the striker's ball
Causing another ball to score its last three hoops and be pegged out during a single turn while the striker's ball remains in play
Making three roquet shots in succession
Running the last three hoops with any ball

correctTheory.title: Advanced Break Play Techniques
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Peeling, advanced tactics, break control
correctTheory.summary: A triple peel is an advanced tactic where the striker causes another ball (the peelee) to score its last three hoops and be pegged out in a single turn, while keeping their own ball in play for tactical advantage.

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Glossary: Triple Peel

questions.question: In Association Croquet, what happens when a ball is roqueted?

answers.answer: The striker's ball becomes dead on the roqueted ball
The roqueted ball is removed from play
The striker gets an extra turn

correctTheory.title: Roquet and Croquet Strokes
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Roquet, croquet stroke, continuation stroke
correctTheory.summary: After a roquet, the striker's ball becomes dead on the roqueted ball and must take croquet before continuing play.
correctTheory.significance: Fundamental rule that enables tactical play and break building
correctTheory.related_concepts: Dead ball status, croquet stroke, continuation stroke

questions.citation: Laws of Association Croquet, 7th Edition, Law 16

questions.question: In break play, what is the key principle for positioning pioneer balls?

answers.answer: Always place them directly in front of hoops
Position them to create a rush after running the hoop

Keep them near the center of the court

correctTheory.title: Break Play Fundamentals
correctTheory.author: John Riches and Wayne Davies
correctTheory.key_concepts: Break play, pioneer positioning, rush setup
correctTheory.summary: Pioneer balls should be positioned to set up a rush after running each hoop, enabling controlled continuation of the break.

questions.question: What is the correct distance between hoops 1 and 2 on a standard court?

correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Court layout, hoop settings, measurements
correctTheory.summary: The standard distance between hoops 1 and 2 is set at 21 yards, as specified in the official WCF court layout diagram. This spacing is crucial for proper game play and standard court setup.

questions.question: Under current rules, what happens if a ball hits the peg when it is not pegged out?

answers.answer: The ball is removed from play

correctTheory.title: Peg Hits and Turn Endings
correctTheory.author: World Croquet Federation
correctTheory.key_concepts: Peg hits, turn endings, ball status
correctTheory.summary: When a ball that is not ready to be pegged out hits the peg, the turn ends immediately. This prevents accidental pegging out and maintains tactical play.

The player who starts the game
